questions.text: During the standard delivery of a primigravida with polyhydramnios, the intern prematurely removes the placenta, leading to profuse bleeding. Examination reveals an intact placenta and that the uterus is partly outside the introitus. The patient is in hemorrhagic shock, so initial resuscitative measures are taken. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Four Classifications Of Uterine Inversion

1st degree (incomplete)

The uterus's top has collapsed inside the uterine cavity

2nd degree (complete):

As a sock turned inside out, the top of your uterus folds into the opening of your uterus (cervix)

3rd degree (prolapsed):

The apex of your uterus enters the vaginal canal at its deepest point

4th degree (total):

The uterus and vagina both protrude from your body

questions.text: What could be the possible cause for the increased bleeding in a G2P1L1 woman who had a previous cesarean section due to fetal distress and now has an uneventful vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC) but an incomplete removal of the placenta, with the cord snapping on traction?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Placenta Accreta

Placenta Increta

Placenta Percreta

Definition

Superficial attachment to myometrium.

Invades into the myometrium.

Invades through the uterine wall to adjacent organs.

Depth of Invasion

Limited to myometrium surface.

Partial invasion of myometrium.

Complete invasion through uterine wall.

Risk Factors

Previous cesarean delivery, placenta previa, uterine surgery.

Same as accreta.

Same as accreta, higher risk with multiple cesareans.

Clinical Features

Postpartum hemorrhage.

Severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Massive hemorrhage, adjacent organ involvement.

Diagnosis

Ultrasound, MRI if needed.

Ultrasound, MRI for depth assessment.

Ultrasound, MRI showing invasion into adjacent organs.

Management

Planned cesarean, hysterectomy if needed.

Cesarean, likely hysterectomy.

Cesarean hysterectomy to prevent complications.

Complications

Hemorrhage.

Severe hemorrhage.

Massive hemorrhage, organ injury.

Prognosis

Good with early diagnosis.

Requires surgical expertise.

High morbidity and mortality risk.

questions.text: How should a patient be managed if a 30-year-old woman, using an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) for contraception, presents to the emergency department after experiencing two episodes of painless vaginal bleeding following 8 weeks of missed periods? She also complains of dizziness, and her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, with a pulse rate of 138 beats per minute. A urine pregnancy test is positive.

options.label: A
options.text: IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate

options.label: C
options.text: Stabilizing the patient followed by suction evacuation

questions.correct_answer: C. Stabilizing the patient followed by suction evacuation

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past one year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis
What is the appropriate course of action for a 24-year-old woman with a complete perineal tear after vaginal delivery?
questions.explanation:
Degree of Tear

Description

Management

1st-degree tear

Superficial tear of the vaginal mucosa

Usually heals spontaneously; may not require intervention

2nd-degree tear

Involves vaginal mucosa and perineal muscles

Repairs with sutures, typically performed soon after delivery

3rd-degree tear

Extends to the anal sphincter

Repairs with sutures, performed soon after delivery or within 24 hours

4th-degree tear

Involves anal sphincter and rectal mucosa

Repairs with sutures, usually requires surgical intervention; performed soon after delivery or within 24 hours

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT, and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus?

options.label: A
options.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery

options.label: B
options.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery

options.label: C
options.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery

options.label: D
options.text: Uterine artery - Pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery

questions.text: A primi at term presented with labor pain and multiple painful vesicular lesions on her vulva. No rashes were found on other parts of the body. What will be the management of this case?
questions.correct_answer: A. Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient came with a history of fatiguability and constipation for the past 1 year. She had a history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery 4 years ago. She has had a lactational failure and never regained her periods after the delivery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Symptoms
  • Failure to lactate
  • Hypotension
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Fatigue
  • Amenorrhea
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Adrenal insufficiency
  • Decreased libido
  • Weight gain
  • Cold intolerance

Diagnosis
  • Clinical history of severe postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Hormonal evaluation: Low levels of pituitary hormones (prolactin, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH, growth hormone).
  • MRI: Empty sella or reduced pituitary size.

Treatment:

Lifelong hormone replacement therapy (glucocorticoids, levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, growth hormone if needed)

questions.text: What is the dose of carbetocin used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Drug/Treatment

Dosage/Administration

Key Notes

Oxytocin (IV)

10-20 units in drip
  • Drug of choice for uterine atony
  • Never give undiluted bolus dose (causes hypotension and arrhythmias)
  • Oxytocin overdose causes water intoxication

Carbetocin

100 mcg in 1 ml IV over 1 min
  • Synthetic analogue of oxytocin, more sustained release
  • Onset: 2 mins, lasts 1 hour (compared to oxytocin's onset of 5 mins and lasts 20 mins)
  • Equivalent to 16 hrs of oxytocin drip

Methylergometrine

0.2 mg IV (also IM, IV acts faster)
  • Peak action in 90 seconds
  • Can be given IM, but IV acts faster

Misoprostol (PGE1)

1000 μg per rectum or 200-400 μg sublingually
  • Prostaglandin used for postpartum hemorrhage
  • Effective for uterine contraction

Carboprost (PGFα)

250 μg IM only
  • Never given IV (causes sudden hypertension)
  • Can be administered intra-myometrial
  • Used when other drugs are ineffective

Tranexamic Acid

1 gm IV
  • Anti-fibrinolytic agent
  • Helps prevent bleeding by inhibiting fibrinolysis

Fibrinogen

Maintain >100 mg/dl
  • For maintaining fibrinogen levels
  • Can be administered as 10 units of cryoprecipitate or 1 litre of fresh frozen plasma (FFP)

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a pregnant woman with high blood pressure, experiencing pain in the abdomen, vaginal bleeding, and a decrease in fetal movements?
questions.explanation:
Placental Abruption

Definition
  • Premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall

Types
  • Marginal abruption (partial detachment)
  • Central abruption (complete detachment)

Risk factors
  • Maternal hypertension
  • Advanced maternal age
  • Previous history of placental abruption
  • Trauma or injury during pregnancy
  • Substance abuse (e.g. cocaine, smoking)

Clinical Presentation
  • Vaginal bleeding, often accompanied by abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness and hypertonic contractions
  • Fetal distress or abnormal heart rate patterns

Diagnosis
  • Clinical evaluation by a healthcare professional
  • Ultrasound imaging to assess placental location
  • Laboratory tests (e.g. complete blood count, coagulation profile)

Management
  • Depends on the severity and gestational age of the fetus
  • Close monitoring of maternal and fetal condition
  • Bed rest and restriction of physical activity
  • Administration of blood products if significant bleeding
  • Delivery of the fetus, either vaginally or by cesarean section

Complications
  • Maternal hemorrhage and shock
  • Fetal growth restriction and distress
  • Preterm birth and associated complications
  • Stillbirth or neonatal death

Postpartum care
  • Monitoring for maternal hemorrhage and infection

questions.text: What is the predominant factor leading to consumptive coagulopathy in the field of obstetrics?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Description

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

DIC is a condition characterized by widespread activation of blood clotting mechanisms, leading to the formation of small clots throughout the body

Preeclampsia

Preeclampsia is a hypertensive disorder that can lead to organ damage, including liver dysfunction, which may trigger consumptive coagulopathy

HELLP syndrome

HELLP syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia characterized by Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy

This rare condition affects liver function and may result in a consumptive coagulopathy due to liver dysfunction

Septic abortion

Septic abortion refers to an infection of the products of conception, which can cause inflammation and abnormal clotting

Placenta percreta/increta/accreta

These conditions involve abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall, which can lead to significant bleeding and coagulation abnormalities

questions.text: n counselling a 39-year-old woman who is G6P2A3 with a history of two previous lower segment Caesarean Sections (LSCS) complicated by placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), which aspect would NOT typically be included in the consent for surgery?
questions.explanation:
Management of placenta accreta spectrum

Placenta Accreta Type

Management

Partial Placenta Accreta

 
  • Remove as much placenta as possible
  • Use oxytocics to control bleeding

Total Placenta Accreta
  • Complete family: Perform hysterectomy
  • Incomplete family:
    • Leave the placenta for autolysis within the uterus and administer antibiotics
    • Consider uterine artery embolisation or Methotrexate therapy

Placenta Percreta with Bladder Invasion

Perform hysterectomy with partial cystectomy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman with a history of Cesarean section and dilatation and curettage presents to the ER with hypotension, tachycardia, and severe abdominal pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable in the abdomen, and the fetal heart rate is weak. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following cerclage procedures would be done in a nonpregnant female through a transabdominal approach?
The given image depicts:

options.label: C
options.text: Both the succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord

questions.correct_answer: C. Both the succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord
questions.explanation:
Condition

Description

Succenturiate placenta

• Extra lobes form separate from the main placental body within the membranes, connected to it by fetal vessels and membranes.

• It occurs only in 5 % of placentas

Bilobed Placenta

Placenta with two roughly equal lobes separated by a membrane.

Placenta accreta spectrum

• Occurs when the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall after childbirth.

• The spectrum has 3 conditions: 

◦ Accreta

◦ Increta

◦ Percreta

• It occurs in 1 out of 2500 pregnancies

Ring-shaped Placenta

An annularly shaped placenta, often resembling a horseshoe due to partial atrophy, is rare.

Placenta Membranacea

A rare condition where chorionic villi cover fetal membranes either partially or completely, occupying the periphery of the chorion.

Circumvallate Placenta

Placenta with raised edges composed of chorion, amnion, and fibrin deposits are associated with poor pregnancy outcomes.

Circummarginate Placenta

 

Similar to the circumvallate placenta but with a flat transition from membranous to villous chorion.

 

Battledore Placenta

An umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than in the centre.

It is associated with pregnancy complications like preterm labour and fetal distress.

Placenta spuria

Unequal placenta not connected by vessel

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?

options.label: A
options.text: Start colloid initially, 4 times the blood lost

options.label: B
options.text: Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth

options.label: C
options.text: PPH is the loss of 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery

options.label: D
options.text: Causes include retained placenta and uterine atony

questions.correct_answer: A. Start colloid initially, 4 times the blood lost
questions.explanation:
Causes of Primary PPH

Cause

Description

Factors increasing risk

Uterine Atony (Most common)

The inability of the uterus to contract effectively after delivery leads to a soft and boggy uterus and continuous bleeding from the placental site.
  • Grand multiparity
  • Overdistension of the uterus: Multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, large baby Malnutrition, and anemia
  • Antepartum hemorrhage: Placenta previa and placental abruption
  • Prolonged labour
  • Anesthesia
  • Oxytocin use.
  • Uterine malformations
  • Other factors: Obesity, h/o PPH, advanced maternal age (over 40 years), tocolytics and magnesium sulfate

Retained Tissue

Prevents proper uterine contraction, causing primary PPH with continued bleeding and incomplete contraction.

Although more commonly associated with secondary PPH, retained placental fragments can also be a cause of primary PPH.

Trauma to the genital tract

Cervical, vaginal, or perineal tears are a significant cause of primary PPH. This type of bleeding occurs despite a well-contracted uterus.
  • Assisted deliveries
  • Rapid labor
  • Large babies

Thrombin (Coagulopathy)

Involves disorders of blood clotting, which are a less common cause of PPH. They can be acquired or congenital.
  • Placental abruption
  • Jaundice in pregnancy
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Intrauterine device (IUD)

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in placenta previa?
questions.explanation:
Types

 

Definitions

I

Low lying

The placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment but does not reach the internal os.

II

Marginal

The edge of the placenta is at the margin of the internal os.

III

Incomplete/partial central

The placenta partially covers the internal os of the cervix.

IV

Central/complete

The placenta completely covers the internal os of the cervix.

Types

Definitions

True Placenta previa

The placenta covers the internal os

Low lying placenta

The placenta lies within 2cm of internal is but does not cover it

questions.text: A female patient with postpartum hemorrhage has been given ergometrine and oxytocin. The bleeding still continues. Which prostaglandin derivative can be given in this situation?
Which of the following is a direct cause of maternal death?
A pregnant woman at 32 weeks, presented with severe abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, and loss of fetal movements. On examination, her uterus is tender. What is the most probable diagnosis?
A partogram of a woman who is in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion is already given. How will you manage the condition?

A 34-year-woman at 30 weeks of gestation is experiencing vaginal bleeding and pain abdomen. She has drenched her clothes and has experienced reduced fetal movements. On examination, her cervix was 6cm dilated and 50% effaced. Her BP was 150/100 mmHg, PR= 100 bpm. Her abdomen corresponded to 34 weeks, and she had a tense and tender uterus with regular contractions and no fetal heart sounds. Her urine protein was 2,+ and there is no active bleeding. What is the ideal management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Antihypertensives + ARM (artificial rupture of membranes)
questions.explanation:
Vaginal delivery is favoured in:
  1. Limited placental abruption.
  2. FHR tracing is reassuring.
  3. Facilities for continuous fetal monitoring are available.
  4. The prospect of vaginal delivery is soon.
  5. Placental abruption with a dead fetus.

Cesarean section is favoured in: (Option B)
  1. Bleeding continues, and the placental abruption is greater than in Grade 1.
  2. Severe abruption with a live fetus.
  3. An amniotomy could not be done due to an unfavourable cervix.
  4. The prospect of immediate vaginal delivery is remote despite attempts.
  5. Amniotomy failed to control bleeding.
  6. Amniotomy failed to arrest the process of abruption, evidenced by rising fundal height or the appearance of adverse features (e.g., fetal distress, falling fibrinogen level, oliguria).
